name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: And third, prepare Taiwan for a long fight by ending strategic ambiguity, providing Taiwan with additional resources for its defense, improving training of Taiwanese forces, and building new joint operational planning structures for the defense of Taiwan.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Second, harness the hardware we have by making use of ships slated for retirement, upgrading our conventional missile arsenal, prioritize buying and modifying weapons that improve our ability to see or strike Chinese forces, and strengthening munitions supply chains.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 80 years later, the memories of these men, and all those impacted in the attack on Pearl Harbor, lives on. And it’s Rep. Gallagher's hope that as we reflect on these stories of service and sacrifice, we’re all inspired to conduct ourselves in a way that’s worthy of their service.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Earl Wallen; Private 1st Class; Marine Corps; USS California.

Mr. Wallen of Pensaukee attended St. Norbert College for a year before enlisting. For his heroic actions St. Norbert granted him an honorary degree and American Legion Post 11 in Green Bay bears his name.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Joseph Muhofski; Radioman 3rd Class; Navy; USS Pennsylvania.
 
Mr. Muhofski was born and raised in Kewaunee, where he is laid to rest with his parents, Joseph and Lucy, at Holy Rosary Cemetery.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Malachy Cashen; Corporal; Army; Wheeler Field.
 
Mr. Cashen attended School in Outagamie County while in the service, and was laid to rest in the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific in Hawaii.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Laxton Newman; Aviation Machinist’s Mate 3rd Class; Navy; Kaneohe NAS.
 
Mr. Newman was from Crivitz. He was awarded a Silver Star Medal for his service and later had a Buckley-class destroyer escort named after him, the USS Newman.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Herbert McLaughlin; Private; Army; Hickman Field.
 
Mr. Mclaughln was from Shawano. The VFW in Shawano is currently named after him. He is tragically still missing in action but is honored at Honolulu Memorial in Hawaii.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Philip Gazecki, Ensign; Navy (reserve); USS Arizona.
 
Mr. Gazecki attended Menasha High, where he was the salutatorian of his class. He later attended Harvard and developed a paint that was used to keep barnacles from attaching to ships in World War II.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
William Bruesewitz, Seaman 1st Class; Navy USS Oklahoma.
 
Mr. Bruesewitz was born in Clinton and lived in Appleton while serving. His body was not identified until 2018, and he was eventually laid to rest in Arlington National Cemetery on the 77th anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Over the last year, @SenAngusKing and I have spent a lot of time referring to Solarium as a 9/11 Commission before 9/11. But the past few months have challenged this framing. The cyber disruption is already here, and it is happening on a near daily basis.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We need to explore how we can provide liability protections for companies to respond in real time against cyberattacks while doubling down on Solarium recommendations to expand federal network defense and public-private collaboration.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Yet these steps will only help if we action them. We need nominations for the National Cyber Director and CISA Director yesterday. We need a declaratory policy when it comes cyberattacks, and we need to signal that we will enforce it ruthlessly.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Thanks to the CSC's tireless efforts and bipartisan collaboration on both sides of the Hill, the FY 21 NDAA was the most significant cyber legislation in US history. We created the National Cyber Director, strengthened CISA, and took steps to ensure continuity of our economy.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Since then, the US has experienced not only the pandemic, but two catastrophic cyberattacks. As we learn more about the recent Microsoft Exchange attacks, I am increasingly concerned about the damage, especially since criminal groups can exploit this vulnerability.

tweet_text: Still, there are more questions than answers. None of this is definitive, and it may well turn out that the virus originated at a wet market and not the Wuhan lab. But the world deserves answers, and as we try to pick up the pieces, the CCP owes humanity a thorough investigation.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The full fact sheet is available here: https://t.co/iYvsshpTUd

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 3) The US government has determined that the Wuhan lab collaborated on secret projects with the Chinese military since at least 2017. We do know if any USG funding for civilian research in Wuhan was diverted to military projects.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 2) Since 2016, the lab in Wuhan had been conducting experiments on a bat coronavirus that is more than 96% similar to COVID-19. The lab altered and then removed online records of its work surrounding this virus.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 1) The USG has reason to believe researchers at the Wuhan Institute of Virology become sick back in autumn 2019, well before the first identified case of the outbreak. Their symptoms were consistent with COVID-19 but also seasonal illness.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As the State Department put it, the "CCP’s deadly obsession with secrecy and control comes at the expense of public health in China and around the world."  In an important fact sheet released just before the Trump administration left office, State chronicled several key points:

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: A year later, as the death toll continues to rise and our economy remains on life support, it's worth taking stock of how we got here. Unfortunately, there is still much we do not know about the virus' origins--including whether it stems from a laboratory accident.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: If we want to stop this chaotic way of governing, if we want to make politics more reasonable, we can't have a giant gap in the heart of our Constitution. Congress has to do its job. Here are some thoughts on how to force Congress to do its job. https://t.co/pKAicWQgDS

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This is not a cheap partisan jab: I made this exact same criticism of the previous administration and voted against Trump's use of emergency executive authority because it ignored Congress's clear constitutional authority to appropriate money. https://t.co/oWvPwwPLBf

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: President Biden is blowing through norms with the sheer volume and scope of these executive orders. That's wrong. But it shouldn't be surprising. The next president, regardless of party, will probably do the same thing.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: That hurts the economy, it sows confusion among citizens, and it often helps the powerful and the connected at the expense of everybody else. That, in turn, raises the stakes for each election - because seemingly everything turns on the outcome.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: In the short term, this behavior wins the praise of partisans. But in the longer term it creates instability and chaos in our constitutional system. Every single election, the disposition of the entire federal government changes on a dime, across a wide range of issues.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: So what happens when Congress decides not to play its part? First, the other branches step in to fill the space. Courts legislate from the bench. The president and bureaucracy tackle problems and policy however they like.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Our constitution is designed to have Congress at the center. We are supposed to be making laws and directing the government. The president and the federal courts are empowered to check Congress, but they are not supposed to replace our legislative authority.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This is THE biggest problem with Congress today. You may have heard that America has three coequal branches. This is wrong. Congress is the dominant branch of government. We are the first branch, and we have the most power over the other two.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Put simply: Congress. Every president issues guidance to the executive branch. That's normal. But when Congress passes bad, vague, or imprecise laws, it opens up space that executive orders fill. In other words, Congress enables presidential discretion.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ President Biden has just issued an unprecedented number of foolish and economically destructive executive orders. So much for unity. You might be wondering how he is allowed to do this. After all, America isn't a dictatorship and the president doesn't make laws.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We cannot let our adversaries succeed, either in letting the embargo lapse or destroying the US veto. I applaud the Trump Administration for its efforts to hold Iran accountable and look forward to ensuring the Iranian regime does not receive a blank check to buy and sell arms.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: What's more, as @Rich_Goldberg argued in @ForeignPolicy over the weekend, the stakes are larger than the arms embargo itself. China and Russia are using the arms embargo to contest the US veto that sits at the heart of the modern multilateral system. https://t.co/jGxGiyNoxu

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: So the question is this: will we use our right--a right that was central to the campaign to sell the JCPOA to the American public--to protect our nation from China, Russia and Iran? Or will we side with China & Russia, and all the nefarious actors who want to buy Iranian weapons?

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: To its credit, the Obama admin negotiated language in a UN Security Council Resolution giving the US the right to snap back all sanctions on Iran at precisely a time like this. If you read UNSCR 2231, it's clear that the US retains that right today.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: In May, I joined nearly 400 members of Congress in urging @SecPompeo to do all he could to keep the embargo alive. China and Russia don't want that to happen. They want to sell Iran advanced weapons and draw US attention away from their malign activities.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD➡️In October, a crucial UN arms embargo of Iran will expire, allowing adversaries like China and Russia to sell the world's leading sponsor of terror advanced weapons that it will use to further destabilize the Middle East, threaten the US, and endanger our allies.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We’d all like to see our allies make larger investments to support our collective defense. But this is not the way to do that. I urge the administration to reconsider this decision. https://t.co/YifymbvN0c

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Cutting our forces in Germany not only reduces our forward presence and our ability to deter aggression in Europe, but it will end up costing us more. Troops leaving Germany will have to go somewhere, and wherever they go, they won’t have the benefit of German financial support.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: To deny, we must be forward. Our forces in Germany are a critical lynchpin of this forward presence. Not only does Germany have unparalleled supporting infrastructure, but it provides millions of dollars to help fund the US presence.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The National Defense Strategy rightly prioritizes these forward forces today. Rather than punish adversary aggression after the fact, the NDS emphasizes a posture of deterrence by denial, which seeks to deny adversaries their attempted conquests in the first place.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The war was a terrible lesson that American needed to defend forward. No longer could we sit back across the ocean and let the storm clouds gather. In the ensuing decades, our forward presence won the Cold War by successfully deterring a Soviet invasion of Western Europe.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The extraordinary sacrifices made on that day of days did not come out of thin air. In the 1930s, deterrence failed, our adversaries saw a free world unwilling to impose costs on aggression, and democracies were late to mobilize against the Nazi war machine.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ 76 years ago today, tens of thousands of Americans, along with our allies, displayed unparalleled courage on the beaches and causeways of Normandy, beginning the long process of liberating Europe from Nazi rule.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We have to be much more vigilant about how the CCP is using the swamp against us. I have legislation that gets at part of this problem, but sunlight is the ultimate disinfectant. The status quo is not acceptable.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Is a former Senator and US Ambassador comparing the President to Hitler on the state channel of a communist dictatorship that has put more than a million of its own citizens into concentration camps gross? Of course. But that's only part of the problem.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Individuals, corporations, or countries that adapt pro-CCP talking points and policies receive lucrative rewards. Those who challenge the Party orthodoxy are punished. We’ve seen this time and again. The CCP relies on foreign elites to promote its interests.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The Party’s core identity, as well as that of its leaders, is tied to these types of influence operations, which the Party calls United Front work. The Party works through elites in capitals worldwide to advance this agenda, connecting economic incentives w/ political compliance.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The CCP credits its underground influence operations for playing a decisive role in its victory in the civil war. As @jgarnaut has argued, many of the key individuals in the CCP today—including Xi —are actually the sons of these espionage artists from the Party’s earliest days.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: While many of the details in the story were shocking, the bottom line shouldn't have been surprising. The CCP was born to take advantage of the swamp. The Party spent its formative years waging an insurgency within China, relying on intelligence activities and irregular warfare.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ This week the @FreeBeacon ran an important story about Max Baucus, who compared the President to Hitler on Chinese state media while pocketing money as an advisor to key Chinese companies. The report touches on a key theme that's worth unpacking. https://t.co/vbGpED5MJ9

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As a Marine, you learn to ride to the sound of the guns. When setting goals as a civilian, exercise that same mentality. Once you’re discharged, go where the action is. Push yourself outside your comfort zone & use the skills you’ve learned to achieve what you want. #VeteransChat https://t.co/wiMR7YmX0G

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Even with a strong support network, I skipped simple tasks and didn’t take advantage of all the resources available to me at the time.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: I would’ve looked for more help. When I discharged, I was eager to start my life. But I didn’t realize just how many resources were available to me in the form of VA benefits and local VSOs. #VeteransChat https://t.co/1FOlrPo8U2

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Incidentally, this ethos of selfless service is what makes veterans such an asset in any workplace. We can work in teams to get difficult jobs done. #VeteransChat

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Officers eat last. We have a duty to help others, to look out for our subordinates first. Particularly those of us who have benefitted from great mentorship in our careers, I believe we have a duty to pay that back. #VeteransChat https://t.co/tpumyLNrjJ

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Be open, be honest, and let your mentor know when you need help. Your mentor has been in your shoes — he or she knows the ins and outs of transitioning back to civilian life and can show you the ropes through even the littlest of matters. #VeteransChat https://t.co/2otQHdBd74

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: You’ll quickly learn there’s a lot of help out there — whether it’s job assistance or free donut Fridays at a local business.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: That’s why I firmly believe that the best resource for veterans are their fellow service members. When you get back, connect with your veteran service officer, your local veteran service organization, or a non-profit that focuses on helping veterans.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Don't be embarrassed to ask for help. Drop the tough guy/gal act and seek assistance (i.e. leadership principle: know yourself and seek self-improvement). There are many resources available to us as veterans — we just have to be willing to ask and learn about them. #VeteransChat https://t.co/E8pTTnCDUh

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As veterans, we have incredible skill sets and leadership traits from our time in service. But it’s on us to translate those skills into success in the civilian world. #VeteransChat

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The belief that our military experience will fit nicely with every civilian job is a common blind spot, in large part because not every civilian company understands fully the nature of military experience or the specific skills we gain from our military occupational specialties. https://t.co/uWjuj0cvEi

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Often we don't realize how overwhelming some of the basics of civilian life can be until after we are discharged. That alone can be a difficult adjustment. #VeteransChat

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Consider how many choices the military makes for you when you're on active duty. Basic things like monthly financial planning, getting a loan for a house, or starting to save for your kids' school may not even cross your radar if you're living on base and deploying all the time.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Recently discharged veterans, myself included, tend to think that the transition to civilian life will be easy. For many, it’s not. Veterans should accept advice during their transition and understand that civilian life comes with challenges we just don't face in the military. https://t.co/Ng9UHcHemD

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Veterans in my area do a remarkable job of helping others find peer mentors. Groups like the NEW Battalion are “the missing link for the transitioning process” and show how veterans support each other as civilians just as they did in combat. #VeteransChat https://t.co/TvQIcKrRoZ

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As veterans, we have different experiences and speak a different language than our civilian counterparts — that can be a difficult adjustment. Having a mentor is vital to better understanding how to operate in the business world, and to bridging the gap we may otherwise have. https://t.co/paJbvDmmw8

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 10. Find strength in our community. Northeast Wisconsin’s strength is the quality and heart of this community. We all need to do our part to help our neighbors, support local nonprofits and businesses, and get through this the way we do best—together.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 9. Reopen state parks, with caveats. More than ever, this is a time where Wisconsinites need to be able to get fresh air and a dose of sanity. Whether it’s closing parking lots, maintaining limited hours, or keeping a skeleton ranger crew on hand, we need to get creative.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 8. Come up with a bipartisan election plan, now. The August primary will be here before we know it, and soon after, November. We should start immediately planning to ensure they go off without a hitch — the legitimacy of our democracy is at stake.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 7. Focus on our dairy farmers. Wisconsin’s dairy sector desperately needs help. Federal funds are a start, but until we break the bottleneck at the processor level, we will be stuck seeing rationing at grocery stores while our farmers are forced to dump excess milk.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 6. School’s in for summer. Our students can’t afford to lose a half year or more of schooling. High schools should consider more online classes, while younger classes may want to make use of empty high schools to move to in person instruction in significantly smaller groups.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 5. Continue to support small business. Congress desperately needs to add resources to the Paycheck Protection Program, which ran through $350 billion in two weeks. Every day we delay putting more money into this program is a day we risk seeing hardworking businesses go under.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 4. Maintain strict social distancing for the most at risk populations, including the elderly and those with compromised immune systems. We’ll have to continue pitching in to help these individuals, as they may not be able to return to normal until a vaccine is widely available.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 3. Develop responsible contact tracing and antibody analysis for individuals who have been infected. The private sector is doing great work in this regard, and we need to leverage these resources and put them to work on behalf of Wisconsinites.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 2. Testing, testing, and more testing. The sooner our labs and hospitals have the ability to provide quick and accessible tests to a majority of Wisconsinites, the sooner we can end the lockdown.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 1. We need a bipartisan task force charged with creating a plan to reopen WI. The task force would bring everyone to the table—state authorities, healthcare experts, businesses large and small, first responders, and educators—and get to work immediately. There’s no time to waste.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ Later today the President will unveil his blueprint to reopen the economy. When that time comes, every state must have a plan in place that caters to their unique situation. As we plan for what’s next in Wisconsin, we should keep the following 10 principles in mind:

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Great joining @LRacheldG on the @DailySignal podcast to discuss why its critical we move our pharmaceutical supply chains out of China, and additional actions Congress should take to combat the Coronavirus. Listen to the full interview here: https://t.co/FlpGnUG3Zn

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This is no time for partisan theatrics. It's time to continue what is working, fix what isn't, support our neighbors, and get through this as we always have--as a community.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: But while we need to fix these pressing issues, we also can’t let this distract from defeating this disease. There aren’t enough dollars to print if we fail to contain this virus, and any additional action should surge more resources and support to the frontlines of the fight.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: I'm glad to see initial reports indicating Congress could add to the pool of PPP resources available for small businesses. Across NEW, small businesses are desperately awaiting the help they need to meet payroll, make rent, and survive another day. Relief cannot come soon enough.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Third, despite Congressional intent, SBA has severely restricted non-payroll loan forgiveness in order to maximize the number of businesses that can benefit from the program. To fix this, Congress should add more funding AND provide more flexibility in how the loans can be used.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Second, we need to support startups—some of which may help prevent future pandemics—by ensuring there’s no confusion around the SBA's affiliation rules. SBA should ensure lenders have the clarity they need to expeditiously make loans to innovative startups.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: At the same time, we still have to address outstanding issues. For one, some lenders are unsure whether PPP eligibility definitions exclude many NEW dairy farms from receiving support. SBA should immediately clarify that dairy farms do not have to meet SBA’s NAICS codes.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: While anything on the scale of the CARES Act will take time, Northeast Wisconsin's small businesses do not have weeks to wait. We must be laser-focused on processing PPP loans as quickly as possible in order to get cash into the hands of those who need it most--yesterday.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ Before speculation about the next Coronavirus relief package gets out of hand, Congress must pause efforts to include special interest projects and ideological pipe dreams. Instead, we need to devote our attention to implementing and fixing what is already on the books.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This was a difficult week for our Navy, but we can’t give up the ship. This morning I talked with @hughhewitt about the situation that unfolded on the TR and ways we can strengthen our maritime security. Listen to our conversation here: https://t.co/5cBG5mhY1k

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: REMINDER: @BrownCoHealth and I are continuing our push to collect PPE for healthcare workers and first responders in NEW. We’ve already received so much from our community, and if you have any gloves, masks, or gowns you can donate, call my office or email WI08donations@gmail.com https://t.co/wr2aAwETl7

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As a maritime nation, our physical security begins and ends with command of the seas. Maritime superiority is not a birthright but a hard-won status we can’t surrender. The task ahead for the Navy and advocates in Congress is not easy, but it is simple: don’t give up the ship.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: In other words, we need a course correction, at flank speed. Front page incidents are starting to pile up, taking with them close to a generation of seasoned leaders. Morale is down. Budgets are inadequate. Enemies are investing heavily in hard power, particularly seapower.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Even as investigations continue, the Navy must turn the page. That starts with Senate-confirmed leadership at the top, a commitment to transparency, and a willingness to communicate a simple vision of geopolitically-informed, integrated American seapower directly to the public.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: While I am grateful for his service, it was no longer tenable for Secretary Modly to lead the Navy. Many Americans rightly have questions about the state of their Navy, and it is imperative that we understand the events that led to Capt. Crozier sending his letter on March 30.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ The past week has been extraordinarily difficult for our Navy. I know the frustration that many sailors might be feeling right now, & I hope they know a grateful nation has their back. America asks its Navy to make incredible sacrifices daily & they do not go unnoticed.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This is an unprecedented crisis that will require unprecedented action. But that doesn’t mean we can allow the relief package to become an Easter basket full of carveouts for corporate & special interests. In this bill we have to put small businesses & vulnerable Americans first.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 3) A focus on community banks. In 2008, one idea that worked was allowing the FDIC to extend unlimited insurance for transaction accounts. This helped prevent a run on small banks and sent a badly needed message that money is safe with local lenders. We should replicate that now.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 2) Immediate and sustained aid to the most vulnerable among us. Paid sick leave is great, but the process is convoluted and doesn’t help those getting laid off. We need to get checks to working Americans now and expand unemployment insurance programs for those who need them.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: 1) A loan program that provides immediate relief to small businesses. These would be paid over a long-term period at 0% interest and allow businesses to delay initial payments up to 3 months, giving employers access to the cash they need to get through the worst of this crisis.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: THREAD ➡️ As we consider a massive stimulus plan, our priority needs to be helping working families and small businesses navigate these difficult times. That will require bold action, and while there is much to address, here are 3 ideas I think could go a long way in helping NEW.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
The idea is that if you have symptoms, you should: 

1. Call your doctor to see if you should get a test
2. Schedule an appointment if so
3. Drive up and get tested
4. Drive home and continue to self-quarantine 

More info on who to call here: https://t.co/FWQCFoirbg

tweet_text: This is an underappreciated aspect of the current disaster, and one that is likely to echo beyond the region. Just as Putin was emboldened to invade Crimea following the Obama admin’s red line fiasco, I am concerned would-be aggressors will look at Syria and see an opportunity.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This all boils down to the credibility of American deterrence. When deterrence breaks down, conflict is more likely and we lose the ability to dictate the terms of engagement.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: If, however, Erdogan was not bluffing, we have even bigger problems because it would mean would-be aggressors do not fear American retaliation. Ask yourself: would Erdogan have felt comfortable risking the lives of 50 Russian service members?

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: In other words, the presence of American service members has successfully helped deter the Turks from taking this kind of action in the past. It’s unclear why this would have suddenly changed, and it suggests that ultimately, Erdogan was bluffing.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: I’m looking forward to hearing from @EsperDoD today, because what we’ve been told so far doesn’t make a lot of sense. Erdogan has been threatening to invade Syria for years now and I’m not sure why we acquiesced after he allegedly gave 48-hours notice.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We should all ask our elected representatives what they are doing in light of the CCP challenge, and these officials should have a good response. This is the greatest international challenge facing the free world. It’s time we start acting like it.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: But for all the progress, we could still choose to bury our head in the sand about the challenge before us. Open conflict with China is avoidable, if we play our cards right, but competition is inevitable. In fact, it’s already here, and it’s happening on a daily basis.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: We’ve come a long way over the past two years in waking up to the threat posed by the CCP. We’ve begun rebuilding our military, we’ve strengthened safeguards against weaponized foreign investment, and we’re in the middle of a major diplomatic campaign about 5G.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Responding to the CCP’s aggression is not a partisan issue. But it will be a defining issue. Across the free world, politicians left, right, & center will be forced to confront the reality that our democracies are facing their greatest challenge in decades.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: To get it out of the way, the CCP leaders overseeing the concentration camps of Xinjiang, where a million or more are being detained largely on account of their religion, are in fact, “bad folks.” But here’s where things get interesting.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Biden has been roundly criticized, and for good reason. But his comments--and the reaction to them--are worth thinking about further.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Yesterday, former VP Biden said that China’s leaders are “not bad folks” and that China does not pose a competitive challenge to the US. This is dangerous thinking, and it’s the logic that led to decades of bipartisan neglect while the CCP worked tirelessly to overtake us.

tweet_text: It’s clear the CCP is using the swamp and our outdated regulations to advance its agenda to the detriment of American interests. It’s time we fought back.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: This is why I introduced HR 1522, the Congressional and Executive Lobbying Ban Act. The bill would prevent former Members of Congress, senior executive branch political appointees, and retired flag and general officers from registering as foreign agents.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: More broadly, senior officials across government should not be able to shop their connections and access on behalf of foreign countries, especially adversaries.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Since apparently lobbying on behalf of a “foreign power” or an “agent of a foreign power” like the CCP does not come with automatic FARA status, it’s time to change the law.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: By offering a bill instead of a budget resolution, my Democratic colleagues on the Budget Committee are neglecting to consider the larger fiscal picture. This is a big problem because there is a looming debt ceiling and budget cap fight, and no one is on the same page.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The Budget Committee is marking up a bill today that would raise budget caps for the next two years and dedicate $733B for defense in FY2020. That’s less than the president's $750B request and applies a dollar-for-dollar increase for defense and non-defense spending.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The whole letter is worth a read. I hope when @jensstoltenberg addresses Congress today, he talks about 5G security and concrete steps NATO is taking to address the challenge. The free world must act with a sense of urgency. https://t.co/G3guhf9Gav

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The letter also raises concerns about the CCP's access to individual data, providing “unprecedented powers of foreign influence to favor authoritarian allies, coerce neighboring countries seeking to preserve their sovereignty, and punish human-rights activists the world over.”

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: From Poland, to the Baltics, and beyond, many of the countries considering Huawei for their 5G networks are US allies that could be on the frontlines of a future conflict. No good can come from highly-networked US forces sending data over compromised networks.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: One of these concerns is the security of future military operations. DoD is currently considering how it could leverage 5G networks to share intelligence or push the immense amounts of data used in military operations. If these networks are Chinese, they're unlikely to be secure.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: So far, mainstream concerns with firms like Huawei have focused on espionage concerns. Given high-profile examples like the African Union headquarters, this focus is understandable. But as the letter describes, espionage is only one of three broad concerns with PRC-supplied 5G.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: I hope we can learn from this. We have enough problems without inventing bogeymen—either from those who repeatedly peddled the collusion narrative or from those who baselessly attacked Mueller’s integrity. We need to work together to ensure this does not become business as usual.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Key individuals who should have known better lied to the public, and in doing so, did serious harm to our national security. They disgraced themselves and, unfortunately, damaged the reputations of their institutions and the many honorable men and women in the IC.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: As a former intelligence officer, I’m gravely concerned by the way the intelligence community (IC) became politicized over the past two years. Officials like Comey, Clapper, Brennan, and Schiff eroded public trust in our IC by wading too deeply into politics and innuendo.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: The simple fact is our media did itself no favors over the past two years. All too often, it delved into clickbait conspiracy rather than objective journalism. This can’t continue, because we really do need the media to hold politicians accountable.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Just imagine for a minute being so opposed to the President that you actively wished he was disloyal to the country and was an agent of a hostile foreign power. It’s crazy and demonstrates the extent to which shallow political combat has become our new national religion.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Which leads to another ugly truth. All Americans should be glad there was no collusion. But you wouldn’t know it by all the disappointed faces on cable news, some of whom are now questioning the integrity of Mueller and Barr.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Part of getting to work means coming to terms with the ugly truths underlying this saga and ensuring something like this never happens again. That means we not only need full disclosure of the report, but also the process that gave rise to the investigation in the first place.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Obviously we need the full report, but AG Barr made his conclusions clear. We need to stop with collusion conspiracy theories and the efforts to change the 2016 election, and get to work on the real problems facing this country.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: Since day one, I’ve emphasized the need for a full and impartial investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Many of my Democratic colleagues called on Republicans to put aside party and stand on principle with Mueller. We did that. Now they must do the same.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text: I've spent the past few days observing the reactions to the findings of Special Counsel Mueller's investigation. I wanted to share my candid thoughts on Mueller's report below. ⬇️

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office

tweet_text: And obviously the bill does not solve the border security problem, it merely punts this problem to the 2020 election, meaning the problem will only get worse.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
The appropriators released a 1100+ page omnibus bill after midnight today. 

We suspended (i.e. violated) the rules to vote on it less than 24 hours later with no real deliberation or debate.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
Why do we have a Congress?

Presumably we have a Congress to deliberate, debate, and legislate. When it comes to border security, Congress has done none of these things.

name: Rep. Gallagher Press Office
tweet_text:
